javaslang

Interface Kind<TYPE extends Kind<TYPE,?>,T>

  • Type Parameters:
    TYPE - container type
    T - component type
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Arbitrary<T>, CheckedMonad<M,T>, Gen<T>, List<T>, Monad<M,T>, Option<T>, Seq<M,T>, Stream<T>, Traversable<M,T>, Try<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Either.LeftProjection, Either.RightProjection, Failure, List.AbstractList, List.Cons, List.Nil, None, Some, Stream.AbstractStream, Stream.Cons, Stream.Nil, Success

    public interface Kind<TYPE extends Kind<TYPE,?>,T>
    A Kind is the type of a type constructor.

    It is denoted as decomposition of a type constructor, i.e. List<T> is Kind<List<?>, T>.

    Higher-kinded/higher-order types cannot be expressed with Java. This is an approximation, it has its limitations.

    Example:

    Javaslang uses Kind to define a function flatMap(Function) in several related classes. The special thing about the Function argument is, that it returns an instance of the type flatMap() is defined in.

    In particular, flatMap() is defined in Monad, Traversable, Seq and List, where List extends Seq, Monad and Seq extends Traversable.

    Here is how it looks like: 

     
 interface Monad<M extends Kind<M, ?>, T> extends Kind<M, T> {
     <U> Monad<M, U> flatMap(Function<? super T, ? extends Kind<M, U>> mapper);
 }

 interface Traversable<M extends Traversable<M, ?>, T> extends Kind<M, T> {
     <U> Traversable<M, U> flatMap(Function<? super T, ? extends Kind<M, U>> mapper);
 }

 interface Seq<M extends Seq<M, ?>, T> extends Kind<M, T>, Traversable<M, T> {
     @Override
     <U> Seq<M, U> flatMap(Function<? super T, ? extends Kind<M, U>> mapper);
 }

 interface List<T> extends Kind<List<?>, T>, Seq<List<?>, T>, Monad<List<?>, T> {
     @Override
     <U> List<U> flatMap(Function<? super T, ? extends Kind<List<?>, U>> mapper);
 }

    See also

    • Generics of a Higher Kind (Moors, Piessens, Odersky)
    • Kind (type theory) (wikipedia)
    • Type constructor (wikipedia)
    Since:
    1.1.0
